habitat_description:
Among newt species, the red-bellied newt has the most restricted distribution; this species occurs in coastal California north of San Francisco Bay, in Sonoma, Mendocino, Lake, and Humboldt counties at elevations ranging from 150 to 450 meters (Twitty 1935; Lannoo 2005; Green et al. 2013). No data is available on the current distribution of this species at any of the historically described localities where once considered abundant in Mendocino County (Lannoo 2005; Twitty 1935, 1959). 
Considered a stream-dwelling species (Stebbins 2003). Egg deposition sites are mountain brook microenvironments, where eggs may be attached to the bottom of rocks in the middle of streams in swiftly flowing water, or attached to exposed roots on the edges of water (Twitty 1942; Lannoo 2005). Juveniles are presumed to stay in underground shelters after metamorphosis until sexual maturity (5 years or longer; Twitty 1966; Twitty et al. 1967). In some of the localities, Pepperwood and Skaggs springs in Sonoma County, individuals were reported on steep, heavily wooded north-facing slopes that erect from the south bank of the breeding stream (Twitty 1966; Licht and Brown 1967).

Distribution of the red-bellied newt follows roughly the distribution of the coast redwood (Sequoia sempervirens; Stebbins 1951; Riemer 1958; Twitty 1964). California laurel (Umbellularia californica) is usually found near one of the described localities (Twitty 1966). Terrestrial adults are often encountered in forests dominated by Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), tan oak (Lithocarpus densiflorus), and madrone (Arbutus menziesii) in southern Humboldt County (Lannoo 2005).
